posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I created a plugin for Recalc that automatically calculates optimal PID gains based on SysId theory for various mechanisms.

This plugin integrates SysId’s theoretical mode into Recalc pages, aiding tuning processes.

Attached is an image showing the plugin interface with a sample PID configuration.

I seeded the cost function controls with appropriate values to prevent edge-case issues in the algorithm.

The current default gains appear reasonable when accurate specs are used, but testing is essential to validate performance.

A live beta version is available at [link], please use correct units during testing.

Note: The original demo link was fixed to work properly.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
The text has been streamlined to eliminate HTML tags, while preserving its core message. Here's the refined version:

A pure JavaScript implementation of the matrix power function capable of handling rational or floating-point exponents would be greatly appreciated—I don't have the capacity to develop such a solution right now. There remains some inaccuracies in the latency correction mechanism when the delay isn't an exact multiple of the loop period. To your knowledge, is there an existing Python implementation for the DARE solver available online? Never mind—I believe I've resolved the issue already.

posts.name: Konnor/RetroBuzz | 5517AM
posts.cooked: I can try it out in a few simulations in several hours. This sounds like a great addition and I will probably make use of it to start my tuning when possible.

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: How do you estimate efficiency effectively? How do you measure measurement delay? Does loop time depend directly on the code’s hertz rate or its actual measured timing?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: What is a good way to estimate or measure efficiency? Multiplicative loss per stage of gearing between the motor and the output, depending on build quality and type of transmission, usually works well enough. How could one measure measurement delay? To do so involves enough hassle that you should use SysId; you can infer an approximate value by examining your motor controller settings and signal chain with some critical thinking. Should loop time be based directly on the hertz of the code or the measured loop times? It depends on where the control loop is running.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: Cycle speed impacts system performance, particularly when comparing shorter versus longer cycle times. My understanding is that both systems maintain consistent maximum speeds, capping at 50Hz for robot control codes and achieving up to 1kHz for TalonFX-based controllers.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: What does this mean? Whether the code will run faster if cycle times are lower? This is a web tool designed to generate theoretical performance metrics; it does not directly influence the robot’s code. The loop operates at its configured speed; you cannot control aspects of the tool beyond those defined by your code. Setting the inputs in the tool to values that don’t align with your code configuration may not yield optimal results, nor guarantee stability.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
I assume it still caps out at 50Hz for robot code and 1kHz for talonfx controllers?  
Yes, by default, the periodic methods of wpilib will be called at a maximum of 50 Hz. You can (and teams do) set up your own loops to run faster. The code itself does not just run as fast as possible even if cycle times are lower.

suggested_topics.title: Socket head vs. button head screws
suggested_topics.fancy_title: Socket head vs. button head screws
suggested_topics.excerpt: Used buttons for decorative surfaces or when smoothness is required. Used sockets when you need more holding force; they take more torque because they take a larger wrench.
